title: The Lilac Sunbonnet: A Love Story
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: "HAUD AFF, WI' YE THERE; MIND WHAUR YER COMIN', YE MUCKLESENSELESS NOWT!" said Jess to her Ayrshire Hornie, who had beentreading on her toes.

title: The Lilac Sunbonnet: A Love Story
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: "STAN' BACK, YE MUCKLE SLABBER!" said Jess, suddenly andemphatically, in a voice that could have been heard a hundredyards away.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: It wasna me he struck ! Weel for him had it been, but I saw the bricht steel flash and the next I kenned was Muckle Sandy Ewan lyin' at my feet wi' a knife hasted sax inch in his throat !"

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Then Muckle Sandy put us aff wi' fair promises.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: (Eh, but he was the bitter weed, Muckle Sandy!) He wad pay to hae Roy McCulloch charged wi' sheep-stealin', and either hung or transported.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Yes, I am the man wha, at Drumfern assize, wadna declare Roy McCulloch guiltless of the blood of Muckle Sandy Ewan.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: "There's a Dumbie here that canna speak," he said, "but nocht will serve him but he maun hae a twa-three words wi' your Lordship ! It's aboot the killin' o' Muckle Sandy Ewan, I'm thinkinM"

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: "The way o't is this," he cried ; "the Muckle Hoose o' Lowran is a' weel an' weel eneuch.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: " 'Aye, a gye queer Buik it'll be, then !' says I. 'Muckle Sandy doesna trouble the Throne o' Grace verra often !'

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: All those things assured the girl that Muckle Sandy Ewan was none so black as he had been painted.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Muckle Sandy Ewan was Anglo- Saxon or what word soever better expresses that colonising,  steadily annexing strain which came forth out of the North German marshes, poured northward through England, and in Dumfries and Galloway became crossed with Scandinavian dourness.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: But when Crob stepped into the wide bare spaces of the "library" and heard Muckle Sandy swear at him, he became at once much more at ease.

snippet: For Adora Gracie was at least one of the causes of Muckle Sandy's present evil case.

snippet: Then through the blind savagery which pain and shame bring to the surface in better men than Muckle Sandy, the dour staunch brain of his race began to work.

title: Strong Mac,

snippet: By far the richest and most determined of all Adora's lovers, and the one whom, in popular estimation, she must end by taking, was Sandy Ewan, the Muckle Sandy of the Lowran Ploughing Match.

snippet: Adora thought wisely that there was no use saying anything  about Muckle Sandy Ewan to her father.

snippet: But the truth was that all unexpectedly Muckle Sandy had come upon an obstacle worse than any stone in the way of his progress cup-wards.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Oh, haste ye haste ye fast ! Oh, the disgrace onybody but Sandy Ewan ! Cast your coat and to it, Strong Mac ! For the honour o' Lowran and to stop Muckle Sandy frae crawin' a' the days o' his life !"

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: "Oh, Mac," panted Jock, tremulous with excitement, "come quick ! For the Lord's sake haste ye, or Muckle Sandy Ewan will carry awa' the Single-handed frae Lowran that has been oors for twenty years.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: "There's no' a lass in a thoosand could hae keepit the schule the day and teached the Muckle Laitin like yon!"

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: With a pleased look on his face Muckle Sandy bent himself away again, like a clever boat on a new tack.

snippet: There was a slight cheer from the Kirkanders men as Muckle Sandy came in.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: What was the anger of Jock Fairies to see with his own eyes Muckle Sandy Ewan conducting a team from his father's farm toward the rigs appointed for the Single- hand competition.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: For at the great ploughing match (which was held alternately upon the farm of Holm, as the nearest to the village, and upon the Kirkanders farm of Boreland, tenanted by the father of Muckle Sandy) it was expected of the tenant whose field was ploughed that he should provide the most copious refreshments.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: For ony boy that gangs to the plooin' match, six ffae me ! For ony lassie that collogues wi' that brute Muckle Sandy Ewan we'll no' let her in, no' though she greets! And hark ye, cronies," he continued, suddenly dropping his monitorial manner, "the less said aboot this at hame the better.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: The classes which followed were child's play to the "Muckle Laitin."

title: Strong Mac,

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Muckle Sandy's hand was already descending, when Strong Mac caught it from behind  and swung the assailant round, as a big dog swings a little one when they are chained together.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Muckle Sandy lifted up his great fist and undoubtedly the next moment the girl would have been lying beside the unconscious Dominie, had not something happened.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Muckle Sandy, stepping over the Dominie, pulled the girl toward him and made another snatch at the ashplant  missed it, and for the third time it stung him vehemently  across one ear.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Muckle Sandy Ewan vented his feelings, after the first intolerable smart of surprise, in a "gowl" of inarticulate wrath.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Before the school could breathe, before the Dominie could quaver a feeble protesting hagyi, before Muckle Sandy Ewan had time to list his weapon, the ash-plant was wrenched out of his hand and he received a couple of stinging cuts with the supple end of it, one across either side of the horse face, on the doughy cheeks of which presently appeared

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Biting his thick under lip till the flat protruding teeth of his upper jaw showed wolfishly, Muckle Sandy stood over the motionless black figure with the ash-plant in his hand.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: The next moment Muckle Sandy had risen, his great horse face distorted with anger.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Their ostensible leader was Muckle Sandy Ewan, a great, raw-boned, horse- faced youth, with pale eyes that seemed "dibbled" into his face, so deeply were they set between his high cheek-bones and the hairless ridges of his eyebrows.
